Characters.Name: American Eel
Characters.Body: I may look like a snake, but I’m really a fish. When it’s time to lay my eggs, I journey hundreds of miles down the rivers of eastern America and far out into the Atlantic Ocean to breed. When the young eels hatch, they return from the ocean to spend their lives in the rivers, and the cycle starts again.

EatenBy.Text: Larger predatory fish, birds of prey, wading birds, small mammals, humans

Characters.FoundIn: Streams, rivers, and muddy or silt-bottomed lakes
Characters.Status: Once abundant, my numbers declined drastically as dams blocked our way through the rivers to our ocean breeding grounds. Eels need the help of conservationists if we’re going to be part of the ecosystem in the future.

Characters.Name: American Shad
Characters.Body: I start life far upstream in freshwater rivers, but move down to the salty waters of the Atlantic to spend my adult life in schools containing thousands of fish. I won’t return to the river for 3-6 years, when it’s time to swim upstream and lay my eggs. I’m an important food source for both animals and humans—so important, in fact, that several U.S. cities host annual shad festivals to celebrate me!

EatenBy.Text: Larger predatory fish, birds of prey, wading birds, otters, bears, humans

Characters.FoundIn: Freshwater rivers and streams for the first months of life and when spawning, coastal Atlantic waters
Characters.Status: Dams and pollution took a toll on our once-huge numbers, and we vanished from many areas. Today, habitat restoration and pollution regulations are helping to rebuild our populations along America’s eastern coast.

Characters.Name: Amphipods (Scuds)
Characters.Genus: Multiple freshwater species in Order Amphipoda
Characters.Body: Most people are completely unaware of the thousands of species of amphipods, or ͞scuds,͟ in aquatic habitats, but we tiny crustaceans serve as an important food source for small animals that, in turn, feed larger animals. In waters with few predators, our populations can reach up to 10,000 per square yard. Our feeding habits help keep water healthy and clean for the other animals that share our habitat.

Eats.Text: Dead plant and animal matter, algae

EatenBy.Text: Small fish, tadpoles, newts, aquatic insects

Characters.Status: We survive in many freshwater environments, but are sensitive to water oxygen levels and erosion. These can have an impact on the size and variety of our populations, which affects animals further up the food chain.

Characters.Name: Bosmina (Water Fleas)
Characters.Body: Although I am commonly called a ͞water flea,͟ I’m really a tiny crustacean, like a shrimp. I use my front legs to comb through the water for microscopic plants and animals, while my back legs have structures that work like nets to capture more. Many creatures rely on me for their food, so I’m a critical link between the algae at the base of the food chain and larger animals at the top.

EatenBy.Text: Small fish, tadpoles, spiders, aquatic insects

Characters.FoundIn: Many freshwater environments, especially well-oxygenated ponds and lakes
Characters.Status: Pollution, overheating of water, lack of oxygen, and dangerous blooms of algae can stress my populations. When that happens, I produce eggs that are carried away on the wind and hatch only when conditions in their landing places are just right.

Characters.Name: Brook Trout
Characters.Body: I’m more than just a fish. I’m a nursery for the tiny young larvae, or ͞glochidia,͟ of freshwater mussels. Floating glochidia attach to my gills, where they live as harmless parasites as they grow. When they’re big enough, the hitchhiking mussels drop off and settle down into the beds of the clear, cold streams that we both need to survive. No brook trout means no mussels!

Eats.Text: Insects, crustaceans, tadpoles, frogs, mollusks, smaller fish

EatenBy.Text: Larger predatory fish, birds of prey, wading birds, small mammals, humans

Characters.FoundIn: Clear, cold streams, rivers, lakes, and ponds
Characters.Status: Habitat loss, erosion, damming, pollution, overfishing, and invasive species have had big effects on my numbers. Brook trout (and mussels) have disappeared from areas where we were once common. We need habitat restoration if we are going to survive.

Characters.Name: Bullfrog
Characters.Body: You may not see us, but you can hear us. Male bullfrogs emit a deep bellow that can be heard up to half a mile away to attract mates and intimidate rivals, especially in the summer breeding season. Our eggs hatch into tadpoles that slowly transform into adult bullfrogs. We’re voracious predators and play a big role in controlling insect populations!

Eats.Text: Insects, worms, crayfish, small fish, small snakes, other frogs

EatenBy.Text: Larger predatory fish, wading birds, snakes, small mammals, humans

Characters.FoundIn: Edges of large, permanent lakes, ponds, and swamps
Characters.Status: Increased water temperatures and increased amounts of water plants—often signs of pollution—actually work to our advantage, providing good habitats for growth, reproduction, and escape from predators. We are becoming much more common in areas that have been changed by humans, driving out other amphibian species in the process.

Characters.Name: Caddisfly
Characters.Genus: In North America, more than 1,000 species within order Trichoptera
Characters.Body: Like many aquatic insects, we spend the early stages of our lives completely underwater as larvae. Unlike other insects, however, our larvae are builders! We produce a silk thread that we use to make food-catching nets, stationary homes, or portable cases by sticking together twigs, gravel, sand, or other debris. When it’s time to transform into adult caddisflies, we shed our armored homes, crawl onto land, and spend the rest of our lives as flying insects.

Eats.Text: Decaying plant and animal matter, algae, small invertebrates

Characters.FoundIn: Streams, rivers, lakes, and permanent or temporary ponds
Characters.Status: Many types of caddisflies are sensitive to water quality and pollution. In fact, counts of our larvae are part of an index widely used by scientists and conservationists to measure water quality.

Characters.Name: Damselfly
Characters.Genus: Multiple species in the suborder Zygoptera in the order Odonata (which also includes dragonflies)
Characters.Body: We may look like dragonflies, but you can tell us apart if you know what to look for. We are usually smaller and more delicate looking than dragonflies, and we hold our wings along our bodies—not outstretched—when resting. We feed on huge quantities of small insects such as mosquitoes and gnats, helping to keep pest populations in check.

EatenBy.Text: Birds, fish, dragonflies, frogs, spiders, aquatic insects

Characters.FoundIn: Bogs, ponds, lakes and rivers with good vegetation
Characters.Status: We are sensitive to water acidity (pH), water temperature, and water flow rates, and vulnerable to pollution and environmental damage. Our presence can be a good indicator that a wetland habitat is relatively healthy and unpolluted.

Characters.Name: Diatoms
Characters.Genus: More than 600 species in Pennsylvania and the northeast
Characters.Body: We are algae, but we encase our soft, singled-celled bodies in hard silica shells that come in an amazing array of geometric designs. Like other algae, we use photosynthesis to turn sunlight into food. In the process, we release oxygen into the water, helping other animals to breathe. We’re the primary food for a wide range of insects, crustaceans, and fish. Without us, life in an aquatic ecosystem can vanish.

EatenBy.Text: Zooplankton, crustaceans, fish larvae, insect larvae

Characters.FoundIn: Sunlit zones of almost any aquatic environment
Characters.Status: When we die, our shells fall into the sediments of rivers, lakes, and oceans. By studying cores taken from these sediments, scientists use our shells to analyze environmental conditions in the past. This helps them understand how pollution, erosion, and climate change are impacting aquatic habitats—and our survival—today.

Characters.Name: Dragonfly
Characters.Genus: Erythemis simplicicollis (Eastern Pondhawk), Pachydiplax longipennis (Blue Dasher), Anax junius (Green Darner), Progomphus obscurus (Sanddragon), Libellula vibrans (Great Blue Skimmer), Celithemis eponina (Halloween Pennant), Libellula lydia (Whitetail Skimmer), Perithemis tenera (Eastern Amberwing)
Characters.Body: For hundreds of millions of years, my kind have been a common sight in many watershed environments, flitting above the surface of the water like flashing jewels in displays of aerial acrobatics. We are ferocious hunters, each one of us eating hundreds of mosquitoes, flies, gnats, midges, and wasps each day.  Because of this, we are important pest controllers, keeping insect populations in check so they don’t overrun a habitat.
Characters.FoundIn: Ponds, marshes, shorelines and surfaces of slow moving creeks and rivers, as well as fast-flowing streams
Characters.Status: Loss of habitat and the pollution of streams are threats to our survival. Many of us need healthy wetland environments with clean water, plants, and healthy insect populations to keep flying.

Characters.Name: Fishing Spider
Characters.Genus: Dolomedes triton and Dolomedes tenebrosus, respectively
Characters.Body: Unlike my web-spinning cousins, I’m completely at home on the water without a web. I can swim by rowing my legs, or rely on the water-resistant hairs all over my body to walk across the surface. I can even dive by trapping a bubble of air between my legs and breathing from it using lungs on my abdomen. I can stay down for more than half an hour with my bubble, hunting prey and hiding from predators.
Characters.FoundIn: Edges of shallow, quiet ponds, lakes, marshes, and streams
Characters.Status: Habitat loss is the biggest threat to my survival. When pollution, erosion, and other environmental factors harm populations of small fish and insects, my food source disappears, and so do I.

Characters.Name: Freshwater Mussel
Characters.Body: I grow slowly, but I can live a long time—as many as 100 years or more! I start life as a tiny larva called a ͞glochidia͟ that requires a fish host to survive until I’m big enough to live on my own. I feed by inhaling water and filtering out tiny organic particles of food. Once, when we were abundant, this filter feeding helped clean the water for all species, but there are so few of us now that we can no longer perform this role in freshwater ecosystems.
Characters.FoundIn: Clean, cold, fast-flowing streams and rivers
Characters.Status: We can’t survive in muddy or silty environments, so erosion and sedimentation of rivers has taken a serious toll on our survival—so serious that we’re now an endangered species. Conservationists are working hard to restore our habitat, save the few of us that are left, and rebuild our populations in the wild.

Characters.Name: Great Blue Heron
Characters.Body: I have specially shaped neck vertebrae that give my head and sharp beak a faster and longer strike than normal, making me a top predator in the wetlands. Herons also like to congregate at fish hatcheries, where prey is easy to come by. Fish farmers didn’t care for us at first, but a study discovered that we mostly ate diseased fish that were easy pickings. Our hunting actually improves the health of the other fish.

Eats.Text: Fish, amphibians, reptiles, large insects, small birds

EatenBy.Text: Large birds of prey, small mammals (especially my eggs)

Characters.FoundIn: Saltwater and freshwater habitats along shorelines, riverbanks, and the edges of marshes, estuaries, and ponds
Characters.Status: We prize mangroves and thick stands of trees for breeding. Pollution and the destruction of these habitats for coastal development had a bad impact on our numbers, but our population has rebounded in recent years due to wetland conservation efforts.

Characters.Name: Largemouth Bass
Characters.Body: Unlike many animals, the male of our species is responsible for the young. He creates a nest in the riverbed where the female lays thousands of eggs. He fiercely guards the eggs until they hatch, and then stays with the school of larvae for up to a month while they feed on tiny animals and grow large enough to survive on their own. If they live long enough, they’ll become one of the largest predators in the watershed.

Eats.Text: Fish, crustaceans, insects, frogs, snakes, small water birds

EatenBy.Text: Birds of prey, small mammals, humans

Characters.FoundIn: Almost any type of freshwater river, stream, lake, or reservoir with abundant prey
Characters.Status: Aquatic plants help slow our voracious hunting by providing cover for prey and making hunting more difficult. When plants disappear due to pollution or habitat degradation, we can decimate other species, and then starve in turn when the prey runs out.

Characters.Name: Maple Leaf
Characters.Genus: In Pennsylvania, Acer rubrum (Red Maple), Acer saccharinum (Silver Maple)
Characters.Body: When maple trees drop their leaves in fall and winter, we drift into streams and ponds. There we decay and create a rich layer of organic matter on the streambed that feeds microorganisms, larval insects, and tiny fish that form the base of a healthy food chain. In spring and summer, I also provide anchors for eggs, hiding places for small fish and insects, and hunting platforms for tiny amphibians, insects, and spiders. A floating maple leaf is an ecosystem all its own!

EatenBy.Text: Plankton, larval insects, larval fish, other microorganisms

Characters.FoundIn: The bottoms of streams, ponds, and lakes
Characters.Status: Like other trees in the watershed, maples pull pollutants out of the air and water, and provide shade that keeps the water cool. Tree roots also hold the land together, controlling erosion, and reducing deposits of sediment that can choke waterways, kill wildlife, and harm water quality.

Characters.Name: Northern Water Snake
Characters.Body: We water snakes are fierce predators, but we are not venomous. I have to hunt by stealth to catch my prey, which I swallow whole. When I feel threatened, I can release a foul-smelling, musky odor to deter predators. However, I’m more likely to escape by submerging beneath the water, where I can stay for up to 90 minutes before coming up for air.

Eats.Text: Tadpoles, fish, frogs, insects, crustaceans, small birds, small mammals

EatenBy.Text: Larger predatory fish, birds of prey, wading birds, small mammals

Characters.FoundIn: Still ponds, lakes, marshes, shores of rivers and streams
Characters.Status: Water snakes are a good indicator of a healthy watershed. When conditions are good and prey is plentiful, you can find us in large numbers, feeding on the many creatures that inhabit the watershed and, in turn, providing food for other animals.

Characters.Name: Nuphar
Characters.Body: My round or heart-shaped leaves can grow up to 12 inches wide. They grow from a long stalk anchored by roots to the muddy bottom. These leaves provide resting places for insects and birds, a place where insects and amphibians can attach their eggs, and shade and shelter for fish. In summer, I grow yellow, globe-like flowers with thick petals that encase a pod loaded with seeds—an unusual relic from the earliest evolution of flowering plants.
Characters.FoundIn: Shallow wetland environments with sluggish/calm waters
Characters.Status: In some areas, invasive plant species have squeezed us out of our natural habitats. Dropping water levels, heating waters, and pollutants are also taking their toll.

Characters.Name: Osprey
Characters.Body: We are unique among North American birds of prey for our strict diet of live fish, and our ability to dive and catch them in water up to three feet deep. We search for fish by flying steadily over or circling high above relatively shallow water. We often hover briefly before diving feet-first to grab our prey. Barbed pads on the soles of our feet help us keep a grip on our slippery meals.

EatenBy.Text: Nothing. I’m at the top of the food chain.

Characters.FoundIn: Coastlines, the shores of freshwater lakes and rivers
Characters.Status: Ospreys are a conservation success story! We were once common in Pennsylvania, but were largely wiped out during the 1950s from the effects of a pesticide called DDT that is now banned. In the 1980s conservationists introduced 6 of us back into the Pennsylvania watershed environment, and now, 35 years later, 100 breeding pairs call this state home.

Characters.Name: Painted Turtle
Characters.Body: As cold-blooded reptiles, soaking up sunlight warms us, gives us the energy to move, and helps rid us of parasites such as leeches that don’t care for light. We like to bask in large groups on logs and rocks. At the first sign of danger, though, our entire group will dive back into the water to hide.

Eats.Text: Aquatic plants, earthworms, insects, crayfish, tadpoles, fish

EatenBy.Text: Large fish, wading birds, raccoons, foxes, snakes, hawks

Characters.FoundIn: Coastlines, the shores of freshwater lakes and rivers
Characters.Status: Ospreys are a conservation success story! We were once common in Pennsylvania, but were largely wiped out during the 1950s from the effects of a pesticide called DDT that is now banned. In the 1980s conservationists introduced 6 of us back into the Pennsylvania watershed environment, and now, 35 years later, 100 breeding pairs call this state home.
